subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... I ve included an example email below. On second thought, we might just want to proceed without posting this questionaire. After all, we kind of know that
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay wrote:


>
> You had mentioned that you wanted to ask posters about how they
> pronounced different words. I think maybe we could start doing this, but
> rather than the way you proposed, maybe we could ask something like "How
> many posters pronounce "On" and "Thought" with the same vowel?" Or "What
> groups of words belong together?" Actually, thinking aloud, this second
> idea sounds even better. We could take all the lexical words from
> problematic sets, mix them up, and then ask users to group them. That
> might be the most useful. So say if I email back and say that I group
> "beer" and "bear" in the same group, and another user writes back and
> says "I could never live with seeing 'beer' and 'bear' written with the
> same vowel," then we know we have a problematic merger and we address it.
>

I've included an example email below. On second thought, we might just
want to proceed without posting this questionaire. After all, we kind of
know that these mergers exist without asking users if they do.

I have made a chart of all my lexical sets, if that would be helpful.

Here is the survey question.

(Note: my asking posters to group words by rhyme won't work--burn and
shirt don't rhyme, but most use the same vowel for them.)

-----------

Hi group,

We are trying to improve our description of the Quikscript alphabet,
and we really need your help. We need to know how you pronounce words.
Don't worry about exact pronunciation. All we really need is for you
to take a look at the following group of words and group them
according to how you pronounce the stressed vowel, and then put the QS
letter used to pronounce the vowel in them. Or, just put the groups of
words together that rhyme.

Some groups will contain words that you pronounce all identical. In
other words, there cannot break up the words. It that case, just say
"I pronounce the vowel in these words all the same," or "Same."


For example, given the following list or
words "cat, blue, hat, boo," I would respond:

cat hat (Ash)

blue boo (Ooze)

Given the words " night, bite, might," I would repsond:

Same (Ice)

Here are the words.


GROUP 1: group these words by how they rhyme, and then put the QS
letter you use for the vowel in the group

horrid adore, store, boar, floor, pour, porch, afford, borne, porter,
oral, mural, curious, flora, glory, laborious, pictorial,
uproarious. boor, poor, tour, endure, Europe, lure, pure, gourmet,
boorish, tourism deplore, more, coarse, court fury, purity

GROUP 2: group these words by how they rhyme, and then put the QS
letter you use for the vowel in the group

aught, naughty, ought, taut, applaud, Nazi, enchilada, Nevada,
autumn, hawk, jaw, chalk, all, bald, calm, balm, psalm, father, long
accost, wash, origin, borrow, florid, moral, sorrow, laurel, quarrel,
stop, rob, Tom, solve, profit, honest, swan, waffle, knowledge, halt,
alter, fault, off, soft, often, Australia, gone, moth, bra, ma, pa,
ah, Bach, salaam, Brahms, Taj Mahal, spa, sonata, bravado,
incommunicado, llama, marijuana, iguana, Koran, rationale,lava, plaza,
almond, drama, panorama

GROUP 3: group these words by how they rhyme, and then put the QS
letter you use for the vowel in the group

beer, here, pier, fear, appear, Korea, museum, care, air, fair, bear,
wear, heir, their, scarce, vary, rarity, dairy, fairy fierce, weird,
beard, serious, dreary, idea, real, ideal

GROUP 4: group these words by how they rhyme, and then put the QS
letter you use for the vowel in the group

hurt, church, curb, far, star, bazaar, sharp, part, harsh, garb,
large, farm, Charles, party, work, worst, heart, turn, burnt, shirt,
firm, twerp, verb, term, certain, earth, heard, rehearsal, journal,
attorney
